nodes.text: A decision tree classifier (J48/C4.5) can be used to predict diabetes status from the Pima Indian diabetes dataset with high accuracy
Context: Data mining classification methods are used in medicine to predict diseases such as diabetes by learning models from training and test data
Method: The Pima Indian Diabetes dataset (768 female subjects, 8 predictive numeric attributes, class 0/1) was used as the data source
Method: J48 (WEKA implementation of C4.5) was applied, using entropy and information gain to select split attributes and optionally pruning; WEKA Explorer was used to build and visualize the tree
Method: Model evaluation used a confusion matrix to compute accuracy and counts of true positives, true negatives, false positives, and false negatives
Claim: Entropy and information gain determine which attribute becomes the root and splits during tree construction
Claim: The proposed J48-based model has advantage over a referenced existing method in accuracy, with a small increase in model build time

Result: The dataset contains 768 records with 8 input variables: pregnancies, plasma glucose, diastolic blood pressure, triceps skin fold, 2-hour insulin, BMI, diabetes pedigree, age, and the class label
Result: J48 handles continuous and discrete attributes, missing values, differing attribute costs, and can produce pruned or unpruned trees
Evidence: WEKA Explorer was used to load diabetes.arff, run J48, visualize the decision tree, and produce evaluation output
Evidence / Result: Model accuracy = 84.1146%; correctly classified = 84.1146%, incorrectly = 15.8854%; TP=468, TN=178, FP=32, FN=90
Result: Entropy of class distribution (268 positive, 500 negative) is 0.9328
Result: Entropy and information gain calculations: plasma feature entropy 0.7996 with gain 0.1332
Result: Entropy and gain for other attributes: BMI entropy 0.8604 gain 0.0724; pregnancy entropy 0.8962 gain 0.0366
Evidence: Compared to an existing method, proposed method accuracy increased by 0.48 percentage points (from 83.63% to 84.1146%) while build time increased by 0.02 seconds (from 0.03s to 0.05s)

Limitation / Conclusion: The Pima dataset contains many zero or missing values (glucose=0 for 5 cases, BMI=0 for 11, blood pressure=0 for 28, skin fold=0 for 192, insulin=0 for 140); deleting such cases reduces dataset to 392 complete cases, so missing data handling is necessary for accurate prediction
